text:
the fact is that although the original folder /
<https://github.com/ta-data-bcn/lab-subsetting-and-descriptive-stats|lab-subsetting-and-descriptive-stats> is a repo, because you have no permissions on that repo, you cannot write to it, therefore you cannot track it as a nested repo - you are not an owner or have a specific role

text:
true. but should not cause an issue.
if i was concerned about which files i wanted to push to git each time and i thought there was a chance i would forget to add specific files when pushing, i would use a .gitignore to exlude that folder entirely from the git process  <https://www.atlassian.com/git/tutorials/saving-changes/gitignore>
this means the folder is simply stored locally as a folder, for local organisation purposes

elements.text:

if i was concerned about which files i wanted to push to git each time and i thought there was a chance i would forget to add specific files when pushing, i would use a .gitignore to exlude that folder entirely from the git process
this means the folder is simply stored locally as a folder, for local organisation purposes

text: I would like to know how to filter in a dataframe a column but with a condition of an other column without creating a new variable, is that possible to do? I'm not sure if I don't remember that lesson or what is it, but I'm checking lots of examples in goolge and none seems to fit

elements.text: I would like to know how to filter in a dataframe a column but with a condition of an other column without creating a new variable, is that possible to do? I'm not sure if I don't remember that lesson or what is it, but I'm checking lots of examples in goolge and none seems to fit

text:
if i am following correctly, there are a few ways to do that - the easiest might be
df.query(‘country==“Spain” & year==2018’)

elements.text:
if i am following correctly, there are a few ways to do that - the easiest might be
df.query(‘country==“Spain” & year==2018’)

text: oh thanks Sian! yes the conditions are any city with temperature > 15, i have problems with that "any city"

elements.text: oh thanks Sian! yes the conditions are any city with temperature > 15, i have problems with that "any city"

text:
simple subsetting with a condition (generates you a boolean column as a "stencil") and then just addressing the city column of that filtered dataframe also works
`df[df["Temperature"] > 15]["city"]`

elements.text: simple subsetting with a condition (generates you a boolean column as a "stencil") and then just addressing the city column of that filtered dataframe also works
df[df["Temperature"] > 15]["city"]

text: if you want, you can then do a unique() on that column to get the unique cities

elements.text: if you want, you can then do a unique() on that column to get the unique cities
